@graph.involvedParties: National Soc. of Professional Engineers v. United States
@graph.reasoning: The term 'restraint of trade' invokes the common law itself, and not merely the static content that the common law had assigned to the term in 1890.

@graph.caseNumber: Copperweld Corp. v. Independence Tube Corp., 467 U. S. 752 (1984)
@graph.involvedParties: Copperweld Corp. v. Independence Tube Corp.
@graph.reasoning: The theoretical underpinnings of earlier decisions are called into serious question.

@graph.involvedParties: GTE Sylvania Inc. v. Consumers Union of United States, Inc.
@graph.reasoning: Schwinn was the subject of continuing controversy and confusion under the great weight of scholarly criticism.

@graph.caseNumber: Albrecht v. Herald Co., 390 U. S. 145 (1974)
@graph.reasoning: Albrecht has been widely criticized since its inception.
Different sorts of agreements may amount to restraints of trade in varying times and circumstances.

@graph.caseNumber: Neal v. United States, 516 U. S.2 84 (1996)
@graph.reasoning: The views underlying Albrecht eroded by this Court's precedent.

@graph.caseNumber: Pattersonv . McLean Credit Union, 491  U. S. 164 (1989)
@graph.reasoning: The views underlying Albrecht eroded by this Court's precedent.

@graph.caseNumber: Rodriguez de Quijas v. Shearson/American Express, Inc.,  490  U.S. 477 (1989)
@graph.involvedParties: Rodriguez de Quijas v. Shearson/American Express, Inc.
@graph.reasoning: The views underlying Albrecht eroded by this Court's precedent.

@graph.caseNumber: Atlantic Richfield Co. v. USA Petroleum Co., 495 U. S. 328 (1989)
@graph.involvedParties: Atlantic Richfield Co. v. USA Petroleum Co.
@graph.reasoning: There has not been another case since Albrecht in which this Court has confronted an unadulterated vertical, maximum-price-fixing arrangement.

@graph.caseNumber: State Oil Co. v. Khan, 522 U. S. 3 (1997)
@graph.reasoning: Vertical maximum price fixing, like the majority of commercial arrangements subject to the antitrust laws, should be evaluated under the rule of reason.
